contextId.occurrenceNote: "In Christ Jesus" and similar expressions are metaphors that frequently occur in the New Testament letters. They express the strongest kind of relationship possible between Christ and those who believe in him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: τοῖς οὖσιν καὶ πιστοῖς ἐν Χριστῷ Ἰησοῦ
contextId.glQuote: who are faithful in Christ Jesus

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings 1) the phrase "in Christ" refers to what Christ has done. Alternate translation: "through Christ" or "through what Christ has done"  or 2) "in Christ" is a metaphor referring to our close relationship with Christ. Alternate translation: "by uniting us with Christ" or "because we are united with Christ" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in Christ

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul speaks of God's grace as if it were material wealth. Alternate translation: "greatness of God's grace" or "abundance of God's grace" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: riches of his grace

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wax was placed on a letter and stamped with a symbol representing the person who wrote the letter. Paul uses this custom as a picture to show how God has used the Holy Spirit to assure us that we belong to him. Alternate translation: "God has sealed you with the Holy Spirit that he promised" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quote: ἐσφραγίσθητε τῷ Πνεύματι τῆς ἐπαγγελίας, τῷ Ἁγίῳ
contextId.glQuote: were sealed with the promised Holy Spirit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Receiving what God has promised is spoken of as though one inherits property or wealth from a family member. Alternate translation: "the guarantee that we will receive what God has promised" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the guarantee of our inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: Receiving what God has promised believers, is spoken of as if one were inheriting property and wealth from a family member. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "head" refers to the leader or the one who is in charge. Alternate translation: "ruler over all things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: head over all things

contextId.occurrenceNote: Just as with a human body, the head (verse 22) rules all things pertaining to its body, so Christ is the head of the church body. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: his body

contextId.occurrenceNote: This shows how sinful people are unable to obey God in the same way a dead person is unable to respond physically. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: ὑμᾶς ὄντας νεκροὺς τοῖς παραπτώμασιν καὶ ταῖς ἁμαρτίαις ὑμῶν
contextId.glQuote: you were dead in your trespasses and sins

contextId.occurrenceNote: people with whom God is angry (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: children of wrath

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to people who were not born Jewish. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Gentiles in the flesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul speaks to the Gentile believers as if they had been foreigners, kept out of the land of God's covenant and promise. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: strangers to the covenants of the promise

contextId.occurrenceNote: Not belonging to God due to sin is spoken of as being far away from God. Belonging to God because of the blood of Christ is spoken of as being brought near to God. Alternate translation: "you who once did not belong to God now belong to God because of the blood of Christ" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: ὑμεῖς οἵ ποτε ὄντες μακρὰν, ἐγενήθητε ἐγγὺς ἐν τῷ αἵματι τοῦ Χριστοῦ
contextId.glQuote: you who once were far away from God have been brought near by the blood of Christ

contextId.occurrenceNote: a single new people, the people of redeemed humanity (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: one new man

contextId.occurrenceNote: Stopping their hostility is spoken of as if he killed their hostility. By dying on the cross Jesus eliminated the reason for Jews and Gentiles to be hostile toward each other. Neither are now required to live according to the law of Moses. Alternate translation: "stopping them from hating one another" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: putting to death the hostility

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul is again speaking of the spiritual condition of Gentiles after they become believers as he would speak about foreigners becoming citizens of a different nation. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: ἐστὲ συνπολῖται τῶν ἁγίων καὶ οἰκεῖοι τοῦ Θεοῦ
contextId.glQuote: you Gentiles ... God's household

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul speaks of God's people as if they were a building. Christ is the cornerstone, the apostles are the foundation, and the believers are the structure. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You have been built on the foundation

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul continues to speak of Christ's family as if it were a building. In the same way a builder fits stones together while building, so Christ is fitting us together. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: πᾶσα οἰκοδομὴ συναρμολογουμένη, αὔξει εἰς ναὸν
contextId.glQuote: the whole building fits together and grows as a temple

contextId.occurrenceNote: "In Christ ... in the Lord Jesus" These metaphors express the strongest kind of relationship possible between Christ and those who believe in him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: In him ... in the Lord

contextId.occurrenceNote: "in Christ" This metaphor expresses the strongest kind of relationship possible between Christ and those who believe in him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes how believers are being put together to become a place where God will permanently live through the power of the Holy Spirit. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: καὶ ὑμεῖς συνοικοδομεῖσθε, εἰς κατοικητήριον τοῦ Θεοῦ ἐν Πνεύματι
contextId.glQuote: you also are being built together as a dwelling place for God in the Spirit

contextId.occurrenceNote: The church is often referred to as the body of Christ. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: fellow members of the body

contextId.occurrenceNote: unable to be completely known (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: unsearchable

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul speaks of the truth about Christ and the blessings he brings as if they were material wealth. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: riches of Christ

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's complex wisdom (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the many-sided nature of the wisdom of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul speaks of their faith as if it were a tree that has deep roots or a house built on a solid foundation. Alternate translation: "that you will be like a firmly rooted tree and a building built on stone" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: that you will be rooted and grounded in his love

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) these words describe the greatness of God's wisdom, Alternate translation: "how very wise God is" or 2) these word describe the intensity of Christ's love for us. Alternate translation: "how much Christ loves us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: τὸ πλάτος, καὶ μῆκος, καὶ ὕψος, καὶ βάθος
contextId.glQuote: the width, the length, the height, and the depth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Walking is a common way to express the idea of living one's life. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: walk worthily of the calling

contextId.occurrenceNote: The church is often referred to as the body of Christ. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: one body

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul is speaking of people who grow spiritually as if they were doing exercises to increase the strength of their physical bodies. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quote: εἰς οἰκοδομὴν τοῦ σώματος τοῦ Χριστοῦ
contextId.glQuote: for the building up of the body of Christ

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul refers to believers who have not grown spiritually as if they were children who have had very little experience in life. Alternate translation: "be like children" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: be children

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of a believer who has not become mature and follows wrong teaching as if that believer were a boat that the wind is blowing in different directions on the water. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: περιφερόμενοι καὶ περιφερόμενοι παντὶ ἀνέμῳ τῆς διδασκαλίας
contextId.glQuote: tossed back and forth ... carried away by every wind of teaching

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul uses the human body to describe how Christ causes believers to work together in harmony as the head of a body causes the body parts to work together to grow healthy. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: εἰς αὐτὸν ... ὅς ἐστιν ἡ κεφαλή
contextId.glQuote: into him who is the head

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul uses the human body to describe how Christ causes believers to work together in harmony as the head of a body causes the body parts to work together to grow healthy. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: ἐξ οὗ πᾶν τὸ σῶμα … τὴν αὔξησιν τοῦ σώματος ποιεῖται εἰς οἰκοδομὴν ἑαυτοῦ ἐν ἀγάπῃ
contextId.glQuote: Christ builds the whole body ... makes the body grow so that it builds itself up in love

contextId.occurrenceNote: They no longer think or reason clearly. Alternate translation: "They have darkened their thoughts" or "They are not able to understand" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: They are darkened in their understanding

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul speaks of these people as if they were objects that they themselves were giving to other people, and he speaks of the way they want to satisfy their physical desires as if it were the person to whom they give themselves. Alternate translation: "only want to satisfy their physical desires" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: have handed themselves over to sensuality

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul is speaking of moral qualities as if they were pieces of clothing. Alternate translation: "to stop living according to your former manner of life" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: ἀποθέσθαι ὑμᾶς κατὰ τὴν προτέραν ἀναστροφὴν
contextId.glQuote: to put off what belongs to your former manner of life

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul is speaking of moral qualities as if they were pieces of clothing. Alternate translation: "to stop living as your former self did" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to put off the old man

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul speaks of the sinful human nature as if it were a dead body falling apart in its grave. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: τὸν φθειρόμενον κατὰ τὰς ἐπιθυμίας τῆς ἀπάτης
contextId.glQuote: that is corrupt because of its deceitful desires

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Holy Spirit assures believers that God will redeem them. Paul speaks of the Holy Spirit as if he were a mark that God puts on believers to show that he owns them. Alternate translation: "for he is the seal that assures you that God will redeem you on the day of redemption" or "for he is the one who assures you that God will redeem you on the day of redemption" or (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quote: ἐν ᾧ ἐσφραγίσθητε εἰς ἡμέραν ἀπολυτρώσεως
contextId.glQuote: for it is by him that you were sealed for the day of redemption

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Put away" here is a metaphor for not continuing to have certain attitudes or behaviors. Alternate translation: "You must not allow these things to be part of your life: bitterness, rage, anger" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: πᾶσα πικρία, καὶ θυμὸς, καὶ ὀργὴ ... ἀρθήτω
contextId.glQuote: Put away all bitterness, rage, anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Walking is a common way to express the idea of living one's life. Alternate translation: "live a life of love" or "always love each other" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: walk in love

contextId.occurrenceNote: Receiving what God has promised believers is spoken of as if it were inheriting property and wealth from a family member. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: Just as one cannot see in the dark, so people who love to sin lack spiritual understanding. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For you were once darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Just as one can see in the light, so people whom God has saved understand how to please God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: but now you are light in the Lord

contextId.occurrenceNote: Walking on a path is a metaphor for how a person lives his life. Alternate translation: "Live as people who understand what the Lord wants them to do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Walk as children of light

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Fruit" here is a metaphor for "result" or "outcome." Alternate translation: "the result of living in the light is good work, right living, and truthful behavior" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: ὁ ... καρπὸς τοῦ φωτὸς ἐν πάσῃ ἀγαθωσύνῃ, καὶ δικαιοσύνῃ, καὶ ἀληθείᾳ
contextId.glQuote: the fruit of the light consists in all goodness, righteousness, and truth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul speaks of the useless, sinful things that unbelievers do as if they are evil deeds people do in the dark so no one will see them. Alternate translation: "Do not do useless, sinful things with unbelievers" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: μὴ συνκοινωνεῖτε τοῖς ἔργοις τοῖς ἀκάρποις τοῦ σκότους
contextId.glQuote: Do not associate with the unfruitful works of darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: actions that do nothing good, useful, or profitable. Paul is comparing evil actions to an unhealthy tree that produces nothing good. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: unfruitful works

contextId.occurrenceNote: Speaking against the works of darkness is spoken of as bringing them out into the light so that people can see them. Alternate translation: "bring them out into the light" or "uncover them" or "show and tell people how wrong these actions are" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: expose them

contextId.occurrenceNote: "people can clearly see everything that comes into the light." Paul makes this general statement in order to imply that God's Word shows people's actions to be good or bad. The Bible often speaks of God's truth as if it were light that could reveal the character of something. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: anything that becomes visible is light

contextId.occurrenceNote: Christ will enable an unbeliever to understand how evil his deeds are and how Christ will forgive him and give him new life, just as light shows what actually is there that darkness hid. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Christ will shine on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Using time wisely is spoken of as if it were redeeming the time. Alternate translation: "Do the best things you can with your time" or "Use time wisely" or "Put time to its best use" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Redeem the time

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "head" represents the leader. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: κεφαλὴ τῆς γυναικὸς … κεφαλὴ τῆς ἐκκλησίας
contextId.glQuote: the head of the wife ... the head of the church

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul speaks of the assembly of believers as though it were a woman whom Jesus will marry. Alternate translation: "for us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: for her

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) Paul is referring to God making Christ's people clean by God's word and through water baptism in Christ or 2) Paul speaks of God making us spiritually clean from our sins by the message as if God were making our bodies clean by washing them with water. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: καθαρίσας τῷ λουτρῷ τοῦ ὕδατος ἐν ῥήματι
contextId.glQuote: having cleansed her by the washing of water with the word

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul speaks of the assembly of believers as though it were a woman whom Jesus will marry. Alternate translation: "make us holy ... cleansed us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: make her holy ... cleansed her

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul speaks of the church as though it were a garment that is clean and in good condition. He uses the same idea in two ways to emphasize the church's purity. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: without stain or wrinkle

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Paul speaks of the close union of believers with Christ as if they were part of his own body, for which he would naturally care. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: we are members of his body

contextId.occurrenceNote: Christians should use all the resources God gives to stand firmly against the devil just as a soldier puts on armor to protect himself from enemy attacks. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: ἐνδύσασθε τὴν πανοπλίαν τοῦ Θεοῦ, πρὸς τὸ δύνασθαι ὑμᾶς στῆναι πρὸς τὰς μεθοδίας τοῦ διαβόλου
contextId.glQuote: Put on the whole armor of God, so that you may be able to stand against the scheming plans of the devil

contextId.occurrenceNote: Christians should use the protective resources God gives them in fighting the devil in the same way a soldier puts on armor to protect himself against his enemies. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: διὰ τοῦτο, ἀναλάβετε τὴν πανοπλίαν τοῦ Θεοῦ
contextId.glQuote: Therefore put on the whole armor of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "stand firm" represent successfully resisting or fighting something. Alternate translation: "so that you may be able to resist evil" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: ἵνα δυνηθῆτε ἀντιστῆναι ἐν τῇ ἡμέρᾳ τῇ πονηρᾷ
contextId.glQuote: so that you may be able to stand in this time of evil

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "stand" represents successfully resisting or fighting something. See how you translated "stand firm" in [Ephesians 6:13](../06/13.md). "So resist evil" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Stand, therefore

contextId.occurrenceNote: Truth holds everything together for a believer just as a belt holds the clothing of a soldier together. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the belt of truth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) the gift of righteousness covers a believer's heart just as a breastplate protects the chest of a soldier or 2) our living as God wants us, gives us a clear conscience that protects our hearts the way a breastplate protects a soldier's chest. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the breastplate of righteousness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Just as a soldier wears shoes to give him solid footing, the believer must have solid knowledge of the gospel of peace in order to be ready to proclaim it. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: καὶ ὑποδησάμενοι τοὺς πόδας ἐν ἑτοιμασίᾳ τοῦ εὐαγγελίου τῆς εἰρήνης
contextId.glQuote: Then as shoes for your feet, put on the readiness to proclaim the gospel of peace

contextId.occurrenceNote: The believer must use the faith that God gives for protection when the devil attacks, just as a soldier uses a shield to protect him from enemy attacks. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: ἐν πᾶσιν ἀναλαβόντες τὸν θυρεὸν τῆς πίστεως
contextId.glQuote: In all circumstances take up the shield of faith

contextId.occurrenceNote: The attacks of the devil against a believer are like flaming arrows shot at a soldier by an enemy. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the flaming arrows of the evil one

contextId.occurrenceNote: Salvation given by God protects the believer's mind just as a helmet protects the head of a soldier. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: take the helmet of salvation

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of God's instructions to his people as if they were a sword that his people could use to fight an enemy, (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quote: τὴν ... μάχαιραν τοῦ Πνεύματος, ὅ ἐστιν ῥῆμα Θεοῦ
contextId.glQuote: the sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God
